Did the New York Times break the law by publishing that story about the National Security Agency? Read my dad's article and find out.:) 
 
 Here is a link: 
 
 http://www.commentarymagazine.com/Production/files/schoenfeld0306advance.html

Did the New York Times break the law by publishing that story about the National Security Agency? Read my dad's article and find out.:) 
 
 Here is a link: 
 
 http://www.commentarymagazine.com/Production/files/schoenfeld0306advance.html

 
 
 What is more important, did the government break laws with their warentless monitoring. There are many who feel that ordering the warrentless wiretaps is an impeachable offense.

Did the New York Times break the law by publishing that story about the National Security Agency? Read my dad's article and find out.:) 
 
 Here is a link: 
 
 http://www.commentarymagazine.com/Production/files/schoenfeld0306advance.html

 
 I plowed through most of your father's article. I'm not a lawyer and unable to judge his case law. 
 
 For the sake of discussion, let's say the Times did knowingly break a law. It took them one year to break the news, which, as a former corporate officer, would mean the finest legal talent money can buy had opined on releasing it.
 
 If a law had, in fact, been broken, I'd assume the risk of prosecution was deemed favorable, that's first amendment and SCOTUS material, when compared to serving the public by publishing that a standing US president was breaking a well-defined law claiming executive power, or facing possible forced impeachment?. 
 
 Is SCOTUS now stacked in Bush's favor or will it ever get there? The attorney general of my country refusing to give sworn testimony to the congressional oversight committee responsible for that AG's adherence to US law? This is almost as hard to swallow as invading a sovereign nation on suspicion of possessing WMDs.

trebor--
 yes, opinion is definitely divided on that question,
 however, the President regularly briefed members of Congress of both parties
 about the program and not one of them objected. So while there can be debate about that, the issue is unclear at best. But what the Times did is not
 unclear--it is an obvious violation of the Espionage Act.

georged-
 you raise a number of interesting points. Commentary has a
 great letters section. You can see it at www.commentarymagazine.com. I bet
 that if you sent in a letter raising those issues, they might publish the
 letter and my dad would answer. 
 
 Is that okay?
 
 I'm really sorry because I know that when people ask questions on here, they expect them to be answered on here. But honestly I am not very well equipped to answer your questions, and if you would like to have them answered, my dad would be happy to do so.

Extremist language:
life-and-death area of national security
I don't know that Bush should be saying this sort of stuff about his administration inasmuch as the NSA fell flat on its face, as did the Bush administration, in saving MY NATION from the September 11, 2001 attack.
 
But is it based on an informed reading of the Constitution and the relevant statutes?
Is such an "informed reading" forthcoming?
 
According to the critics, many of whom base themselves on a much-cited study by the officially nonpartisan Congressional Research Service
Oh, OK, I suppose it is not necessary for an attorney to have mastered impeccable English, if Mr. Schoenfeld is, indeed, an attorney but, gosh, how the heck can an individual base him or herself on a much-cited study. One's opinions might be based on such a study, or one's conclusions but, the totality of one's self? Is that humanly possible.
 
 Pah!

Your point is a form of nitpicking. If you disagree with the article, do so. But pointing to errors that are not really errors is really not a productive way to carry on a debate. It is fully possible to base oneself on a study. In fact, it is an elegant formulation.

update:
 If any of you have cable, my dad (Gabriel Schoenfeld) will be on msnbc tonight, February 13, at 6 PM, to discuss the article.
 
 I don't have cable so I won't be watching it emoticon_cry
